title: Homework 2
text:
Create vectors for pretreatment data (x) and after treatment data (y)


x <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)

y <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)


Assign names to the subjects within each vector


names(x) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

names(y) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")


x

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 



y

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 



Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient and save a new vector z


z <- (y-x)
z

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
         7         -6         10         -4          0        -10         -9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
        -3         -8        -10          5         24         -7        -21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       -12         -8        -19        -18         -7        -17 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients.


mean(z, trim = 0, na.rm = FALSE)

[1] -5.65



Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change).


which(z>0)

 Subject_1  Subject_3 Subject_11 Subject_12 
         1          3         11         12 



Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.


p <- which(z>0)
p

 Subject_1  Subject_3 Subject_11 Subject_12 
         1          3         11         12 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those where the blood pressure decreased (positive change).


mean(p, trim = 0, na.rm = FALSE)

[1] 6.75






Create a data frame object with four columns corresponding to your data above: patient, pre_bp, post_bp, and diff_bp


df <- data.frame("pre_bp" = x, 'post_bp' = y, "diff_bp" = z)
df

           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1     120     127       7
Subject_2     151     145      -6
Subject_3     125     135      10
Subject_4     126     122      -4
Subject_5     115     115       0
Subject_6     132     122     -10
Subject_7     132     123      -9
Subject_8     129     126      -3
Subject_9     134     126      -8
Subject_10    139     129     -10
Subject_11    127     132       5
Subject_12    122     146      24
Subject_13    127     120      -7
Subject_14    135     114     -21
Subject_15    133     121     -12
Subject_16    128     120      -8
Subject_17    147     128     -19
Subject_18    138     120     -18
Subject_19    140     133      -7
Subject_20    132     115     -17



Return only rows of the data frame where the diff_bp column is negative. (Use [ or learn about the subset() function if you’d like. If you use [, don’t reference the original vector from the first part, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison with 0.)

subset(df, diff_bp < 0, select = pre_bp:diff_bp, drop = FALSE)

           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_2     151     145      -6
Subject_4     126     122      -4
Subject_6     132     122     -10
Subject_7     132     123      -9
Subject_8     129     126      -3
Subject_9     134     126      -8
Subject_10    139     129     -10
Subject_13    127     120      -7
Subject_14    135     114     -21
Subject_15    133     121     -12
Subject_16    128     120      -8
Subject_17    147     128     -19
Subject_18    138     120     -18
Subject_19    140     133      -7
Subject_20    132     115     -17

df

           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1     120     127       7
Subject_2     151     145      -6
Subject_3     125     135      10
Subject_4     126     122      -4
Subject_5     115     115       0
Subject_6     132     122     -10
Subject_7     132     123      -9
Subject_8     129     126      -3
Subject_9     134     126      -8
Subject_10    139     129     -10
Subject_11    127     132       5
Subject_12    122     146      24
Subject_13    127     120      -7
Subject_14    135     114     -21
Subject_15    133     121     -12
Subject_16    128     120      -8
Subject_17    147     128     -19
Subject_18    138     120     -18
Subject_19    140     133      -7
Subject_20    132     115     -17


Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the post_bp is less than 120 and FALSE if it is not. Similar to the previous question, don’t reference the original vector from task 1, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison. Recall you can use $ to access a column. If you reference a column that doesn’t exist and save a vector (of appropriate length in it), that vector becomes a column of your data frame! Use this way of creating the new column.


df$new <- with(df, ifelse(post_bp > 120, 'False', 'True'))
df

           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp   new
Subject_1     120     127       7 False
Subject_2     151     145      -6 False
Subject_3     125     135      10 False
Subject_4     126     122      -4 False
Subject_5     115     115       0  True
Subject_6     132     122     -10 False
Subject_7     132     123      -9 False
Subject_8     129     126      -3 False
Subject_9     134     126      -8 False
Subject_10    139     129     -10 False
Subject_11    127     132       5 False
Subject_12    122     146      24 False
Subject_13    127     120      -7  True
Subject_14    135     114     -21  True
Subject_15    133     121     -12 False
Subject_16    128     120      -8  True
Subject_17    147     128     -19 False
Subject_18    138     120     -18  True
Subject_19    140     133      -7 False
Subject_20    132     115     -17  True



Finally, print the data frame out nicely in your final document by modifying the code below appropriately.


knitr::kable(df)





pre_bp
post_bp
diff_bp
new

120
127

False


Subject_2
151
145
-6
False


Subject_3
125

False


Subject_4
126

-4
False


Subject_5
115

True


Subject_6
132

-10
False


Subject_7
132
123
-9
False


Subject_8
129

-3
False


Subject_9
134

-8
False


Subject_10

-10
False


Subject_11

False

-7

True

False

True


Subject_19

False


Subject_20
132
115
-17
True









Create a new data frame with this data in it that is similar to the data frame from task 2 (including the new column of TRUE/FALSE values).


xt <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
yt <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)
names(xt) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")
names(yt) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")
zt <- (yt-xt)

dft <- data.frame("pre_t" = xt, 'post_t' = yt, "diff_t" = zt)

dft$newt <- with(dft, ifelse(post_t > 120, 'False', 'True'))

dft

           pre_t post_t diff_t  newt
Subject_1    138    105    -33  True
Subject_2    135    136      1 False
Subject_3    147    123    -24 False
Subject_4    117    130     13 False
Subject_5    152    134    -18 False
Subject_6    134    143      9 False
Subject_7    114    135     21 False
Subject_8    121    139     18 False
Subject_9    131    120    -11  True
Subject_10   130    124     -6 False



Now create and store a list with two elements: • 1st element named treatment and contains the first data frame you created. • 2nd element named placebo and contains the second data frame you created.


my_list <- list('treatment' = df, "placebo" = dft)
my_list

$treatment
           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp   new
Subject_1     120     127       7 False
Subject_2     151     145      -6 False
Subject_3     125     135      10 False
Subject_4     126     122      -4 False
Subject_5     115     115       0  True
Subject_6     132     122     -10 False
Subject_7     132     123      -9 False
Subject_8     129     126      -3 False
Subject_9     134     126      -8 False
Subject_10    139     129     -10 False
Subject_11    127     132       5 False
Subject_12    122     146      24 False
Subject_13    127     120      -7  True
Subject_14    135     114     -21  True
Subject_15    133     121     -12 False
Subject_16    128     120      -8  True
Subject_17    147     128     -19 False
Subject_18    138     120     -18  True
Subject_19    140     133      -7 False
Subject_20    132     115     -17  True

$placebo
           pre_t post_t diff_t  newt
Subject_1    138    105    -33  True
Subject_2    135    136      1 False
Subject_3    147    123    -24 False
Subject_4    117    130     13 False
Subject_5    152    134    -18 False
Subject_6    134    143      9 False
Subject_7    114    135     21 False
Subject_8    121    139     18 False
Subject_9    131    120    -11  True
Subject_10   130    124     -6 False



Access the first list element using three different types of syntax (the result can be a list or just the data frame).


my_list[1]

$treatment
           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp   new
Subject_1     120     127       7 False
Subject_2     151     145      -6 False
Subject_3     125     135      10 False
Subject_4     126     122      -4 False
Subject_5     115     115       0  True
Subject_6     132     122     -10 False
Subject_7     132     123      -9 False
Subject_8     129     126      -3 False
Subject_9     134     126      -8 False
Subject_10    139     129     -10 False
Subject_11    127     132       5 False
Subject_12    122     146      24 False
Subject_13    127     120      -7  True
Subject_14    135     114     -21  True
Subject_15    133     121     -12 False
Subject_16    128     120      -8  True
Subject_17    147     128     -19 False
Subject_18    138     120     -18  True
Subject_19    140     133      -7 False
Subject_20    132     115     -17  True



my_list[[1]]

           pre_bp post_bp diff_bp   new
Subject_1     120     127       7 False
Subject_2     151     145      -6 False
Subject_3     125     135      10 False
Subject_4     126     122      -4 False
Subject_5     115     115       0  True
Subject_6     132     122     -10 False
Subject_7     132     123      -9 False
Subject_8     129     126      -3 False
Subject_9     134     126      -8 False
Subject_10    139     129     -10 False
Subject_11    127     132       5 False
Subject_12    122     146      24 False
Subject_13    127     120      -7  True
Subject_14    135     114     -21  True
Subject_15    133     121     -12 False

Subject_17    147     128     -19 False
Subject_18    138     120     -18  True
Subject_19    140     133      -7 False
Subject_20    132     115     -17  True



str(my_list[1])

List of 1
 $ treatment:'data.frame':  20 obs. of  4 variables:
  ..$ pre_bp : num [1:20] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 ...
  ..$ post_bp: num [1:20] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 ...
  ..$ diff_bp: num [1:20] 7 -6 10 -4 0 -10 -9 -3 -8 -10 ...
  ..$ new    : chr [1:20] "False" "False" "False" "False" ...



Use your list from question 2. In one line of code, access the pre_bp column of the placebo data frame.


my_list[[2]][1]

           pre_t
Subject_1    138
Subject_2    135
Subject_3    147
Subject_4    117
Subject_5    152
Subject_6    134
Subject_7    114
Subject_8    121
Subject_9    131
Subject_10   130

title: Homework 2
text:
Create vectors for pretreatment data (x) and after treatment data (y)


x <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)

y <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)


Assign names to the subjects within each vector


names(x) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

names(y) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")


x

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 



y

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 



Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient and save a new vector z


z <- (y-x)
z

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
         7         -6         10         -4          0        -10         -9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
        -3         -8        -10          5         24         -7        -21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       -12         -8        -19        -18         -7        -17 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients.


mean(z, trim = 0, na.rm = FALSE)

[1] -5.65



Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change).


which(z>0)

 Subject_1  Subject_3 Subject_11 Subject_12 
         1          3         11         12 



Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.


p <- which(z>0)
p

 Subject_1  Subject_3 Subject_11 Subject_12 
         1          3         11         12 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those where the blood pressure decreased (positive change).


mean(p, trim = 0, na.rm = FALSE)

[1] 6.75

title: Homework 2
text:
Create a new data frame with this data in it that is similar to the data frame from task 2 (including the new column of TRUE/FALSE values).


xt <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
yt <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)
names(xt) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")
names(yt) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")
zt <- (yt-xt)

dft <- data.frame("pre_t" = xt, 'post_t' = yt, "diff_t" = zt)

dft$newt <- with(dft, ifelse(post_t > 120, 'False', 'True'))

dft

Subject_1    138    105    -33  True

Subject_6    134    143      9 False

Subject_9    131    120    -11  True
Subject_10   130    124     -6 False
